case_vignette: A 16-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of fever and poor feeding for 2 days. He became very fussy the previous evening and cried for most of the night. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and weighed 2430 g (5 lb 3 oz). The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother does not recall any sick contacts at home. He currently weighs 2776 g (6 lb 2 oz). He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. He becomes more agitated when picked up. There is full range of motion of his neck and extremities. The anterior fontanelle feels soft and flat. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Blood cultures are drawn and fluid resuscitation is initiated. A urinalysis obtained by catheterization shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a fever and not feeding well for the past two days, and I was very fussy and cried a lot last night.
How old is the patient?
I am a 16-day-old newborn.
Has the newborn been vomiting or having diarrhea?
No, I haven't been vomiting or having diarrhea.
Has the newborn been in contact with anyone who is sick?
No, my mother does not recall any sick contacts at home.
Is there any family history of genetic disorders or metabolic conditions?
There is no mention of any family history of genetic disorders or metabolic conditions.
**Final Diagnosis:** Neonatal Sepsis
